metadata.titleEn: Daily cloudless MODIS Snow area ratio data set of the QTP (2000-2015)
metadata.description:
The daily cloudless MODIS Snow area ratio data set (2000-2015) of the Qinghai Tibet Plateau is based on MODIS daily snow product - mod10a1, which is obtained by using a cloud removal algorithm based on cubic spline interpolation.
The data set is projected by UTM with spatial resolution of 500m, providing daily snow cover FSC results in the Tibetan Plateau. The data set is a day-to-day document, from 24 February 2000 to 31 December 2015. Each file is the result of snow area proportion on that day, the value is 0-100%, which is envi standard file, the naming rule is: yyyddd_fsc_0.5km.img, where yyyy represents the year, DDD represents Julian day (001-365 / 366). Files can be opened and viewed directly with envi or ArcMap.
The original MODIS Snow data product for cloud removal comes from the mod10a1 product processed by the National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC). This data set is in the format of HDF and uses the sinusional projection.
The attributes of the daily cloudless MODIS Snow area ratio data set (2000-2015) on the Qinghai Tibet Plateau consist of the spatial-temporal resolution, projection information and data format of the data set.
Temporal and spatial resolution: the temporal resolution is day by day, the spatial resolution is 500m, the longitude range is 72.8 ° ~ 106.3 ° e, and the latitude is 25.0 ° ~ 40.9 ° n.
Projection information: UTM projection.
Data format: envi standard format. File naming rules: "yyyyddd" + ". Img", where yyyy stands for year, DDD stands for Julian day (001-365 / 366), and ". Img" is the file suffix added for easy viewing in ArcMap and other software. For example, 2000055 ﹐ FSC ﹐ 0.5km.img represents the result on the 55th day of 2000. The envi file of this data set is composed of header file and body content. The header file includes row number, column number, band number, file type, data type, data record format, projection information, etc.; take 2000055 ﹣ FSC ﹣ 0.5km.img file as an example, the header file information is as follows:

background: Snow cover changes over the Tibetan plateau (TP) are examined using moderate resolution imaging spectroradiometer (MODIS) daily fractional snow cover (FSC) data from 2001 to 2011 as well as in situ temperature data.
research objective: The objective of this study is to provide a reliable and up-to-date analysis of variations in snow cover over the TP by taking advantage of long-term, continuous observations from MODIS daily FSC data, and how they are related to the changing temperature.
challenges: However, the extensive and persistent cloud coverage in MODIS snow cover products is the main limitation in many applications. Although all of these approaches are particularly useful for reducing the cloud cover pixels, they sacrifice temporal and spatial resolution and introduce some uncertainties to different degrees.
methods: First, the accuracy of the MODIS FSC data under clear sky conditions is evaluated by comparing with Landsat 30-m observations. Then we describe a cloud-gap-filled (CGF) method using cubic spline interpolation algorithm to fill in data gaps caused by clouds. Finally, the spatial and temporal changes of snow cover are analyzed on the basis of the MODIS-derived snow-covered area and snow-covered days (SCD) data.
dataset: The MOD10A1 FSC data, for the period 2001 to 2011, are used in this study. Those coded integer values of the MOD10A1 FSC data over the TP include 0 to 100 (fractional snow), 200 (missing data), 201 (no decision), 225 (land), 237 (inland water), 250 (cloud), 254 (detector saturated), and 255 (fill; no data expected for pixel). In situ daily air temperature data from 102 meteorological stations of the Chinese Meteorological Administration (CMA) are used to analyze the relationship between the snow cover and air temperature. In situ SCD data from 2001 to 2006 at 93 stations (which are located in the study area) are applied to validate the MODIS-derived SCD map.
findings: These results indicate that the MOD10A1 daily FSC data has sufficient accuracy to reflect snow cover information over the TP.

background: Snow cover, as an important component of land cover, is one of the natural materials on the Earth’s surface with wide distribution, obvious seasonal variation, and high sensitivity to climate change. Snow plays an important role in the global energy and water cycles because of its high albedo and thermal and water storage properties, and can indicate the changes in global climate. Studying snow cover variation is of great importance in monitoring and maintaining water management for ecosystem processes and irrigation practices. In arid and semi-arid regions of Western China, snow cover is a very important water resource, since water from melted snow forms the headwaters for several of the largest rivers in Asia. Consequently, snow can also largely influence agriculture and animal husbandry. More importantly, more than one sixth of the global population relies on water from mountainous snowmelt. The Tianshan Mountains, as the water tower of Central Asia, are the source of major rivers in Central Asia. Snow cover in Tianshan Mountains, is an important predictor of regional climate change, as well as a crucial water source for its surrounding arid regions, and greatly influences the hydrological and biological processes. However, due to the scarcity and limitation of meteorological station, the in-situ snow cover observations are difficult to adequately quantify the spatiotemporal variability of snow cover in the mountainous regions. Recent technological advances in satellite remote sensing have allowed remote sensing data to extract the information of snow cover in the inaccessible areas with rugged terrain and hostile climate. The most recent and advanced remote sensing snow cover product is produced by the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) flown on the Earth Observing System (EOS) Terra and Aqua platforms. Evaluation studies have suggested a high accuracy of MODIS snow cover products under clear skies, when comparing with the in-situ observations and other higher resolution satellite data at both regional and global scales. However, the extensive cloud obscuration in MODIS snow cover products greatly limits their applications. The spatiotemporal variation of the snow cover is affected substantially by both the temperature and precipitation. As one of the most sensitive and prominent areas responding to global climate changes, the temperature of the Tianshan Mountains in Central Asia has increased more than twice the rate of global warming in the past decades. The state of high variability in temperature of the Tianshan Mountains has led to changes in mountainous hydrological processes and water resources, and increased the runoff in the Tianshan Mountains due to the accelerated glacier/snowmelt.
research objective: In this work, we investigate the spatiotemporal variations of snow cover in the Tianshan Mountains during 2001–2015, based on the cloud removed daily MODIS FSC data, and the possible linkages between snow cover and two main climate parameters (temperature and precipitation). The specific aims are to examine the snow cover variations in the Tianshan Mountains during the state of high variability in temperature of the Tianshan Mountains since 1998 and to address the possible cause for the snow cover changes from the perspective of climate factors.
challenges: However, due to the scarcity and limitation of meteorological station, the in-situ snow cover observations are difficult to adequately quantify the spatiotemporal variability of snow cover in the mountainous regions. The extensive cloud obscuration in MODIS snow cover products greatly limits their applications. These methods can effectively reduce the cloud obscuration in the daily MODIS binary snow-cover maps for the monitoring of snow cover dynamics. However, they sacrifice temporal and spatial resolution and introduce some uncertainties to different degrees.
methods: In this study, the MOD10A1 data for 2001–2015 from the National Snow & Ice Data Center (NSIDC) are employed to investigate snow cover variations in the Tianshan Mountains. Using the MODIS Reprojection Tool (MRT), the MOD10A1 FSC data are mosaicked and resampled from the original 463.3 m pixel size to 500 m, and georeferenced into a UTM projection with a datum of WGS84. Based on this cloud removal method, the daily cloud-free MODIS FSC datasets in Tianshan Mountains from 2001 to 2015 are produced. To investigate the spatiotemporal variations of snow cover, we obtain the snow-covered area (SCA) and snow-covered days (SCD) from daily cloud-free MODIS FSC data and examine them from the study area and the four subregions. Pearson correlation analysis is used to investigate the correlations between snow cover (SCA or SCD), and temperature and precipitation dynamics for the 15 years (2001–2015).
dataset: In this study, the MOD10A1 data for 2001–2015 from the National Snow & Ice Data Center (NSIDC) are employed to investigate snow cover variations in the Tianshan Mountains. The daily MOD10A1 FSC products, including five MODIS tiles (h22v04, h23v04, h23v05, h24v04 and h24v05), are used in this study. Daily temperature and precipitation and snow depth data from 47 meteorological stations in the Tianshan Mountains for 2001–2015 are collected from China Meteorological Administration and NOAA’s National Centers for Environmental Information.
findings: The distribution of snow cover over the Tianshan Mountains exhibits a large spatiotemporal heterogeneity. In total, 26.39% (5.09% with a significant decline) and 34.26% (2.81% with a significant increase) of the study area show declining and increasing trend in SCD, respectively. The snow cover variations are linked to the temperature and precipitation changes. Temperature tends to be the major factor affecting the snow cover changes in the Tianshan Mountains during 2001–2015.

Definition.Question: What is the 'cloud-gap-filled (CGF)' method in the context of snow cover data collection?
Definition.Answer: The 'cloud-gap-filled (CGF)' method refers to a technique that uses a cubic spline interpolation algorithm to fill in data gaps caused by clouds in MODIS snow cover products. This method aims to address the limitation of cloud coverage in MODIS data, which can obscure snow cover information and reduce the utility of the dataset.

Definition.Question: What does 'fractional snow cover (FSC)' mean in the context of remote sensing datasets?
Definition.Answer: 'Fractional snow cover (FSC)' in remote sensing datasets refers to the proportion of an area covered by snow, expressed as a percentage ranging from 0 to 100. It provides a detailed quantification of snow cover extent within a given pixel, allowing for more nuanced analysis of snow cover changes over time.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'cloud removal method' in satellite snow cover data analysis?
Definition.Answer: A 'cloud removal method' in satellite snow cover data analysis involves techniques used to reduce or eliminate the effects of cloud cover in satellite images. This is done to ensure clearer and more accurate observation of snow cover data, overcoming the challenges posed by cloud obstruction in MODIS snow cover products.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do cloud removal methods using cubic spline interpolation for MODIS data differ from other approaches in terms of preserving spatial and temporal resolution?
Comparison.Answer: The cubic spline interpolation method for cloud removal in MODIS data aims to fill data gaps caused by clouds while attempting to preserve spatial and temporal resolution. However, like other cloud removal methods, it may sacrifice some resolution and introduce uncertainties. The comparison highlights that while cubic spline interpolation is beneficial for reducing cloud cover, it shares the challenge of potential resolution loss with other methods.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in snow cover variability analysis between using MODIS-derived snow-covered area and snow-covered days datasets?
Comparison.Answer: MODIS-derived snow-covered area (SCA) focuses on spatial coverage of snow, while snow-covered days (SCD) provide information on temporal persistence of snow cover. Analyzing SCA can reveal spatial distribution and heterogeneity, whereas SCD can highlight temporal trends and duration of snow presence. Both datasets can be correlated with climate parameters like temperature and precipitation to understand snow cover dynamics, but they emphasize different aspects of variability.

Interpretation.Question: How can the cubic spline interpolation algorithm used in data collection methods help infer the reliability of cloud-free snow cover datasets over mountainous regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The cubic spline interpolation algorithm is a cloud-gap-filled method that helps fill in data gaps caused by clouds in MODIS snow cover products. This approach improves the reliability of cloud-free datasets by reducing the temporal and spatial resolution sacrifices and uncertainties introduced by cloud coverage, thus offering a more accurate depiction of snow cover over mountainous regions.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways do challenges like extensive cloud coverage in MODIS snow cover products influence the interpretation of snow cover data over large geographical areas?
Interpretation.Answer: Extensive cloud coverage limits the applications of MODIS snow cover products by introducing data gaps and uncertainties, which can hinder the accurate quantification of snow cover variation over large geographical areas. This challenge necessitates the implementation of cloud-gap-filled methods, such as cubic spline interpolation, to ensure continuous and reliable snow cover datasets for analysis.

Interpretation.Question: What role does the integration of in situ temperature and snow cover data play in interpreting the correlation between climate factors and snow cover variability?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating in situ temperature and snow cover data allows researchers to analyze the correlation between climate factors and snow cover variability. By comparing MODIS-derived snow-covered area and snow-covered days data with in situ observations, researchers can validate the satellite data's accuracy and explore the influence of temperature and precipitation dynamics on snow cover changes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the extensive and persistent cloud coverage in MODIS snow cover products, and how do these factors impact data collection and analysis in mountainous regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The extensive and persistent cloud coverage in MODIS snow cover products is a major limitation in many applications. This cloud coverage affects the accuracy and usability of the data by obscuring the surface, which is especially challenging in mountainous regions with rugged terrain. Methods such as cubic spline interpolation are used to fill data gaps caused by clouds, but they may sacrifice temporal and spatial resolution and introduce uncertainties.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the scarcity and limitation of meteorological stations a challenge for quantifying spatiotemporal variability of snow cover in mountainous regions, and how does remote sensing address this challenge?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The scarcity and limitation of meteorological stations make it difficult to adequately quantify the spatiotemporal variability of snow cover in mountainous regions due to the complex terrain and harsh climate. Remote sensing, particularly using MODIS products, allows for the extraction of snow cover information in inaccessible areas. However, cloud obscuration in these products remains a challenge, though methods exist to reduce cloud cover effects.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of implementing a cloud-gap-filled method using cubic spline interpolation on the spatial and temporal resolution of MODIS snow cover datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing a cloud-gap-filled method using cubic spline interpolation can effectively reduce cloud cover pixels in MODIS snow cover datasets, but it might also sacrifice temporal and spatial resolution to some degree and introduce uncertainties.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the scarcity of meteorological stations impact the accuracy and reliability of snow cover data collection in mountainous regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The scarcity of meteorological stations can limit the ability to adequately quantify the spatiotemporal variability of snow cover in mountainous regions, potentially affecting the accuracy and reliability of data collection.

Goal Orientation.Question: What objectives could drive the development of a cloud removal algorithm for MODIS snow cover datasets over regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to provide a reliable and up-to-date analysis of variations in snow cover by reducing the extensive and persistent cloud coverage in MODIS snow cover products, which is a main limitation in many applications. This allows for continuous observations and analysis of snow cover and its relation to temperature changes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What could be the intention behind utilizing both remote sensing data and in-situ measurements to study snow cover changes in areas with limited meteorological stations?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intention is to adequately quantify the spatiotemporal variability of snow cover in mountainous regions where direct observations are limited. Remote sensing data can cover inaccessible areas, while in-situ measurements provide validation, resulting in a comprehensive understanding of snow cover dynamics.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in removing cloud cover from MODIS snow cover data to ensure accurate snow cover analysis?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The process involves using a cubic spline interpolation algorithm to fill in data gaps caused by clouds in the MODIS snow cover products. This method helps in producing daily cloud-free MODIS fractional snow cover datasets for analysis.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the accuracy of MODIS fractional snow cover data validated against higher resolution satellite data or in-situ observations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The accuracy is evaluated by comparing the MODIS fractional snow cover data under clear sky conditions with Landsat 30-m observations and in-situ daily air temperature data from meteorological stations to analyze the relationship between snow cover and air temperature.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are employed to integrate temperature and precipitation data with snow cover datasets for climate impact studies in mountainous regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Pearson correlation analysis is used to investigate the correlations between snow cover (snow-covered area or snow-covered days) and temperature and precipitation dynamics. This involves collecting daily temperature, precipitation, and snow depth data from meteorological stations to examine their influence on snow cover variations.

Enablement.Question: What data processing techniques enable the removal of cloud coverage from MODIS snow cover products to enhance their accuracy and applicability?
Enablement.Answer: A cloud-gap-filled (CGF) method using a cubic spline interpolation algorithm is employed to fill in data gaps caused by clouds, improving the accuracy and applicability of MODIS snow cover data.

Enablement.Question: How do advancements in satellite remote sensing technology enable the extraction of snow cover information in remote and rugged terrains?
Enablement.Answer: Recent technological advances in satellite remote sensing, such as MODIS on the Terra and Aqua platforms, allow for the extraction of snow cover information in inaccessible areas with rugged terrain and hostile climates, despite challenges like cloud coverage.

Expectation.Question: Why might data collection techniques for snow cover over the Tibetan plateau face challenges in reducing cloud cover while maintaining spatial and temporal resolution?
Expectation.Answer: The extensive and persistent cloud coverage in MODIS snow cover products presents challenges, as methods to reduce cloud cover pixels often compromise temporal and spatial resolution, introducing uncertainties to a certain extent.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected challenges in accurately quantifying snow cover variability in mountainous regions using satellite remote sensing data?
Expectation.Answer: The scarcity and limitation of meteorological stations make in-situ snow cover observations challenging for adequately quantifying the spatiotemporal variability of snow cover in mountainous regions. Additionally, cloud obscuration in MODIS snow cover products is a significant limitation.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the cubic spline interpolation method works to reduce cloud cover in satellite snow cover data.
Assertion.Answer: The cubic spline interpolation method is used to fill in data gaps caused by clouds in satellite snow cover data. It relies on mathematical interpolation to estimate and replace missing values, thereby producing a more complete dataset for analysis without sacrificing the temporal and spatial resolution significantly.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how MODIS snow cover data can be validated using in-situ observations.
Assertion.Answer: MODIS snow cover data can be validated using in-situ observations by comparing the satellite-derived snow cover data with ground-based measurements collected from meteorological stations. This comparison helps to evaluate the accuracy of the satellite data under clear sky conditions and ensures that the observed snow cover information is reliable.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the methodologies used to reduce cloud cover impact in remote sensing datasets for snow cover analysis over mountainous regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: The dataset employs a cloud removal technique using a cubic spline interpolation algorithm to fill in data gaps caused by clouds, which is a challenge due to extensive and persistent cloud coverage in MODIS snow cover products. This method helps to obtain daily cloud-free MODIS fractional snow cover datasets.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges and limitations of using in-situ observations for snow cover variability studies in remote and mountainous regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: A significant challenge is the scarcity and limitation of meteorological stations, which makes it difficult to adequately quantify the spatiotemporal variability of snow cover in mountainous regions. This limitation can affect the accuracy and completeness of snow cover data derived from in-situ observations.
